questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements about the anatomy of the gallbladder is false?

options.a: Valves of Heister are present around the neck of the gallbladder
options.b: Gall bladder has a very thick submucosal layer
options.c: Hartmann's pouch may hinder safe dissection of the cystic pedicle
options.d: Phrygian cap anomaly is not an indication for cholecystectomy

questions.explanation:
The gallbladder does not have muscularis mucosa and submucosa. Those layers are absent in the 
gallbladder. The mucosa of the cystic duct is arranged in spiral folds known as the valves of the Heister. The 
valves act to keep gallstones from entering the common bile duct in spite of distention and 
intraluminal pressure. Hartmann’s pouch is a diverticulum that can occur at the neck of the gallbladder. It may obscure 
the cystic duct and Calot’s triangle during laparascopic surgical dissection. The Phrygian cap is present in 2–6 percent of cholecystograms and may be mistaken for a 
pathological deformity of the organ. It is not an indication for cholecystectomy.

questions.question:
Question 2: While assisting a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for gallstones, the surgeon asks you to identify 
the Calot's triangle. Which of the following structures does not form the boundaries of this 
triangle?

options.d: The inferior surface of the liver

questions.explanation:
744 
Sold by @itachibot The inferior surface of the liver forms the boundary of the hepatobiliary triangle, not Calot’s 
triangle. Calot's triangle is an important surgical landmark as the cystic artery usually can be found within 
its boundaries. The cystic artery should be identified while performing a cholecystectomy to avoid 
damage to the extrahepatic biliary system. Occasionally, there can be a tortuous course of the right hepatic artery in some patients. This is 
called Moynihan's hump or caterpillar hump. It is an important anomaly that should be 
recognized in order to prevent intraoperative vascular and biliary injuries. Note: The cystic artery is one of the contents as well as forms the superior boundary of the Calot's 
triangle (originally described in 1891 by Jean-François Calot)

questions.question: Question 3: Which type of gallstones is most likely to be seen in the Asian population?
questions.explanation:
The most common type of gallstone to be seen in the asian population is pigment stone (80%). 
The most common type of gallstone worldwide is mixed stone. Three main types of gallstones include: • Cholesterol stones - They consist of cholesterol monohydrate crystals. Pure cholesterol stones 
are uncommon and account for <10% of all cases. • Pigment stones (brown or black) contain <30% cholesterol: • Black stones - Made up of insoluble bilirubin pigment polymer mixed with calcium phosphate 
and calcium bicarbonate. They are associated with hemolysis, usually seen in hereditary 
spherocytosis or sickle cell disease. • Brown stones - Contain calcium bilirubinate, calcium palmitate, and calcium stearate, as well as 
cholesterol. They are also associated with the presence of foreign bodies within the bile ducts, 
such as endoprostheses (stents), or parasites, such as Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris 
lumbricoides. 745 
Sold by @itachibot • Mixed stones. The image below shows a resected specimen of the gallbladder with pigment stones. Struvite stone (triple phosphate stone) is a type of renal calculi. It is made of magnesium, 
ammonium, and phosphate.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 28-year-old obese woman underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and the specimen of 
gallstones removed is given below. Which of the following is least likely to be a risk factor for 
the formation of this type of gallstone in her? 732 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above image shows cholesterol gallstones. Hereditary spherocytosis is not a risk factor for the 
formation of cholesterol gallstones. Hereditary spherocytosis leads to the production of black 
pigment stones. Obesity, high-caloric diets, prolonged fasting, certain medications (e.g., oral contraceptives), and 
resection of the terminal ileum result in increased secretion of cholesterol and supersaturation of 
bile. This enhances the lithogenicity of bile.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 45-year-old woman was brought to the casualty with complaints of abdominal pain and 
vomiting. CT scan of the abdomen revealed the following finding. What is the most probable 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The CT image shows the Mercedes-Benz sign. It is a characteristic sign seen in gallstones. In gallstone, rarely, the center of the stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate 
fissure. This gives rise to characteristic dark shapes on a radiograph called the Mercedes–Benz 
sign (triradiate sign) or seagull sign (biradiate sign). 746 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: What percentage of gallstones are radio-opaque?
questions.explanation:
Only 10% of gallstones are radiopaque. Approximately 90% of renal stones, 10% of gall stones, and 5% of appendicoliths contain enough 
calcium to appear radiopaque on plain films. Gallbladder diseases are regularly diagnosed by ultrasound because of the superficial location of 
the gallbladder and the absence of overlying bowel gas. Ultrasound has a high specificity and 
sensitivity for cholelithiasis. It is considered as the first test of choice for delineation of any biliary 
pathology. Stones appear acoustically dense and also produce an acoustic shadow. They also move 
with a change in posture. However, CT provides superior anatomic information and therefore is 
indicated when more anatomic delineation is required. 747 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: While performing the HIDA scan in a patient with gallstones, the gallbladder was not 
visualized. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Non-visualization of the gallbladder in HIDA (hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid) scan is suggestive 
of acute cholecystitis. Acute cholecystitis is the inflammation of the gallbladder that develops over hours, usually 
because a gallstone obstructs the cystic duct. In the majority of cases, the process is limited by the 
stone slipping back into the body of the gallbladder. Clinical features include: • Pain in the right hypochondrium with referred pain to the back • Fever • Nausea, vomiting, dyspepsia • Jaundice • Positive Murphy's sign • Positive Boas' sign Murphy's sign: After asking the patient to exhale, the examiner places his hand below the costal 
margin on the right side at the mid-clavicular line of the patient. The patient is then instructed to 
take a deep inspiration. If the patient stops breathing and winces with a ‘catch’ of breath, 
Murphy’s sign is said to be positive. Boas' sign: It is the presence of an area of hyperaesthesia at the site of radiation of the pain to the 
back, typically, below the scapula. USG and CT scans are helpful in establishing a diagnosis. The gold standard investigation of acute 
cholecystitis is the HIDA scan. The radioisotope used is Technetium-99m ( 99mTc)-labeled 
derivative of iminodiacetic acid. The following image depicts the radioisotope scan in which the gallbladder is not visualized even 
after 4 hours. 748 
Sold by @itachibot Unlike bilirubin, iminodiacetic acid (IDA) compounds do not undergo conjugation in the 
hepatocytes. They are rapidly excreted into the bile. This enables excellent visualization of the bile 
ducts and gallbladder within 30–60 minutes of injection. Since cystic duct obstruction initiates acute cholecystitis, there is non-visualization of the 
gallbladder 3 - 4 hours after the intravenous injection of 99m Tc-IDA. This is characteristic of 
acute cholecystitis. Thus visualization of the GB establishes cystic duct patency and rules out acute 
cholecystitis.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 25-year-old patient was admitted with right hypochondriac pain and vomiting. USG 
demonstrates a stone within the bile duct. All of the following clinical features can be seen in 
this patient except:
questions.explanation:
The presence of a stone within the bile duct is called choledocholithiasis. Murphy's sign is not 
seen in choledocholithiasis. It is seen in acute cholecystitis. Clinical features of choledocholithiasis: • Right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, which may radiate to the back • Biliary colic • Vomiting • Dyspepsia • Flatulence • Food intolerance particularly to fatty foods • Altered bowel habits • Jaundice. Other Murphy's in surgery: Murphy's punch sign: This test is performed by the examiner using the fist to make jabbing 
thrusts over the costovertebral angle. The test is positive in infection, inflammation, or 
obstruction of the kidney. The angle shown in the image is the costovertebral angle formed between the lower border of 
the 12th rib and the vertebral column. 749 
Sold by @itachibot Murphy's triad is associated with acute appendicitis. • Pain in the right illiac fossa • Vomiting • Fever

questions.question:
Question 9: 734 
Sold by @itachibot According to the Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for grading the severity of acute cholecystitis, 
which of the following conditions is classified under moderate (Grade II) acute cholecystitis?
questions.explanation:
If the duration of complaints is >72 hours, the patient is classified as having moderate (Grade 
II) acute cholecystitis. Acute cholecystitis is treated by keeping the patient nil per oral (NPO), administering intravenous 
fluids, analgesics, and IV antibiotics. The timing of surgery in acute cholecystitis remains controversial: • If the patient presents within 3 days, emergency cholecystectomy is done. • If the patient presents after 3 days, conservative management is done initially. Once the 
inflammation subsides, cholecystectomy is performed after 6 weeks (interval cholecystectomy). Tokyo Consensus Guidelines

questions.question:
Question 10: A 45-year-old man with a past medical history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension and 
ischemic heart disease presented with fever, nausea and right upper abdominal pain for the 
past 2 days. On evaluation, he is hypotensive and has a right upper quadrant palpable mass. 
Laboratory findings are mentioned below. Which of the following is the most appropriate 
management for this patient?

options.a: Percutaneous cholecystostomy, followed by interval cholecystectomy
options.c: Conservative management, followed by delayed cholecystectomy after 6 weeks

questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of severe acute cholecystitis (grade III) based on Tokyo 
Consensus Guideline. Patients who have multiple comorbidities and present with severely acute 
cholecystitis should ideally undergo USG guided percutaneous cholecystostomy, followed by 751 
Sold by @itachibot interval cholecystectomy once the condition has been stabilized.. Management of cholecystitis • Nil per oral (NPO) • IV fluids • Analgesics • IV antibiotics • Surgery • Grade III • with comorbidities - a percutaneous cholecystostomy can be performed by a radiologist under 
ultrasound guidance. An interval cholecystectomy once the condition has been stabilized. • without comorbidities - unless the patient is extremely hemodynamically unstable, operative 
intervention (cholecystectomy) should be performed. • Grade I-II • presenting within 3 days - emergency cholecystectomy is done. • presenting after 3 days - conservative management is done initially. Once the inflammation 
subsides, cholecystectomy is performed after 6 weeks (interval cholecystectomy). Tokyo Consensus Guidelines

questions.question:
Question 11: A diabetic patient presents with complaints of right upper quadrant pain, fever and nausea. 
On examination, there is tenderness over the right upper quadrant. CT scan revealed the 
following finding. What is the most common organism implicated in this condition? 735 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the CT scan showing gas within the wall of the gallbladder are 
diagnostic of acute emphysematous cholecystitis. Clostridia species are the most commonly 
implicated organisms in acute emphysematous cholecystitis. Other causative organisms include E. 
coli and anaerobic streptococci. Emphysematous cholecystitis is a rare form of acute cholecystitis where gallbladder wall necrosis 
causes gas formation in the lumen or wall. Clinical features include: • Right upper quadrant pain • Nausea • Vomiting • Fever • Presence of crepitus during physical examination On imaging, the condition is diagnosed when there is a radiographic demonstration of air in the 
gallbladder wall +/- biliary ducts. 753 
Sold by @itachibot Emphysematous cholecystitis has a high mortality rate due to the development of gangrene, 
perforation, and other complications. Hence, emergency cholecystectomy is indicated for the 
management of these patients. Tube cholecystostomy is done for patients who are not suitable for 
surgery. The given image shows a postoperative specimen of an emphysematous gallbladder along with an 
X-ray showing air in the gallbladder wall. Note: E. coli is the most commonly implicated organism in acute emphysematous pyelonephritis.

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient in the burns ward complains of right hypochondriac pain and fever. USG reveals a 
thickened, hyperemic gallbladder with sludge formation surrounded by pericholecystic fluid 
but no gallstones. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

options.a: CT-guided cholecystostomy is the treatment of choice
options.b: It has a high mortality rate
options.d: E. coli is the causative agent

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the USG findings point to a diagnosis of acalculous 
cholecystitis. E. coli is not a causative agent of acalculous cholecystitis. Acute and chronic inflammation of the gallbladder can occur in the absence of stones and are 
referred to as acalculous cholecystitis. It is mainly seen in critically ill patients and those recovering from major surgery, trauma, and 
burns. It has a high mortality rate. The bacterial infections of the gallbladder causing acalculous cholecystitis include: • Leptospira • Streptococcus • Salmonella • Vibrio cholerae Clinical features are similar to that of acute calculous cholecystitis, such as: • Right upper quadrant pain • Fever 754 
Sold by @itachibot • Positive Murphy's sign • Leukocytosis • Sepsis A USG demonstrates a distended gallbladder with thickened wall, biliary sludge, pericholecystic 
fluid, and the presence or absence of abscess formation. HIDA scan shows a non-visualization of 
the gallbladder. Acalculous cholecystitis requires urgent intervention. Percutaneous ultrasound or CT-guided 
cholecystostomy is the treatment of choice for these patients, as they are usually unfit for surgery. Cholecystectomy is performed after the patient has recovered from the underlying illness.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 25-year-old lady was incidentally found to have gallstones during the abdominal 
ultrasound. She is otherwise healthy and does not complain of any symptoms. In which of the 
following clinical scenarios you will not advise her for prophylactic cholecystectomy?
questions.explanation:
Prophylactic cholecystectomy in asymptomatic cholelithiasis is indicated only when gallstones 
>3 cm. Indications for consideration of prophylactic cholecystectomy in asymptomatic patients: • Risk factors for carcinoma • Choledochal cysts • Gallbladder adenomas • Porcelain (calcified) gallbladder • Solitary gallbladder polyp larger than 1 cm • Choledocholithiasis • Gallstones >3 cm • The patient lives in a remote location from a healthcare facility • Sickle cell disease/spherocytosis • Transplant or immunosuppressant therapy. Note: Some books also mention "Prophylactic cholecystectomy is indicated in asymptomatic 
cholelithiasis when gallstones >2 cm."

questions.question:
Question 14: Medical therapy for gallstones using ursodeoxycholic acid will be considered in all of the 
following conditions, except:

options.a: If the size of the cholesterol stone is < 10mm
options.b: If the patient has biliary pain without any complications
options.d: In the presence of radio-opaque cholesterol gallstones

questions.explanation:
Medical therapy using ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) for gall stones is indicated for radiolucent 
cholesterol stones. Selection criteria for oral bile acid dissolution therapy: • Symptomatic patients without complications • Patients with normal gallbladder functioning and a patent cystic duct • Patients with radiolucent stones and diameter < 10 mm 755 
Sold by @itachibot Stones >10 mm in size rarely dissolve. Patients with cholesterol gallstone disease who develop 
recurrent choledocholithiasis after cholecystectomy should be on long-term treatment with UDCA. 
The dose of UDCA should be 10–15 mg/kg per day. Pigment stones are non-responsive to UDCA therapy.

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient with symptomatic gallstones but refusing surgery is at risk of developing all of the 
following complications except:
questions.explanation: Diverticulosis is not a complication due to gallstones. Clinical complications due to gallstones include the following: • Biliary colic • Acute cholecystitis • Chronic cholecystitis • Empyema of the gallbladder • Mucocele • Perforation • Biliary obstruction • Acute cholangitis • Acute pancreatitis • Intestinal obstruction (gallstone ileus).

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following statement is false regarding the mucocele of the gallbladder?

options.a: Caused due to prolonged obstruction of cystic duct
options.b: Early cholecystectomy needs to be done
options.c: Obstruction can be seen in the neck of the gallbladder
options.d: A tender, non palpable gallbladder is characteristic of this condition

questions.explanation:
The gallbladder is palpable but non-tender in the mucocele of the gallbladder. Mucocele of the gallbladder results from prolonged obstruction of the cystic duct, usually by a 
large solitary calculus. The obstructed gall bladder lumen is progressively distended by mucus 
(mucocele) or by a clear transudate (hydrops) produced by mucosal epithelial cells. It is usually asymptomatic, although chronic right upper quadrant pain may also occur. On 
examination, a visible, easily palpable, non-tender gallbladder, sometimes extending from the 
right upper quadrant into the right iliac fossa may be seen. Ultrasonography is helpful for the diagnosis. Early cholecystectomy needs to be done, because empyema, perforation, or gangrene may 
complicate the condition. The image below shows mucocele of the gallbladder. 756 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows empyema of the gallbladder.

questions.question:
Question 17: A middle-aged woman with a history of cholelithiasis was rushed to the casualty with 
complaints of vomiting, abdominal distension, and obstipation. On examination, high-pitched 
bowel sounds were heard. Her X-ray erect abdomen is given below. Which statement is false 
regarding this condition? 737 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: It is associated with Rigler's triad
options.b: Jejunum is the most common site of obstruction
options.c: CT scan is the investigation of choice
options.d: Enterotomy is done in the absence of strangulation

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with an X-ray showing gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) and 
multiple air-fluid levels indicating small bowel obstruction is suggestive of gallstone ileus. The 
distal ileum is the most common site to be obstructed in gallstone ileus because it tapers before 
entering the cecum. Gallstone ileus is caused by the obstruction of the intestinal lumen by a gallstone, leading to a 
mechanical blockage. Big gallstones will not be able to pass through the normal cystic duct. This 
causes inflammation of the gallbladder and results in pressure necrosis. This in turn leads to 
biliary-enteric fistula formation. 757 
Sold by @itachibot Plain radiographs demonstrate air-fluid levels consistent with a small bowel obstruction. Rigler's 
triad is seen in gallstone ileus. It includes: • Intestinal obstruction • Gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) • Ectopic gallstone (Radio-opaque shadow in the right iliac fossa) The investigation of choice is the CT scan. Pneumobilia is a ubiquitous finding because the fistula 
that permitted a stone to pass into the duodenum allows air into the gallbladder and the biliary 
tree. Initial management involves keeping the patient nil per-oral, IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and 
analgesics. If there is no strangulation or peritonitis, it can be managed by: • Milking the stone beyond ileocaecal junction • Crushing the stone • Enterotomy to remove the stone If there is perforation or strangulation, resection and anastomosis are done. Cholecystectomy should be performed to avoid future complications. Fistula closure can be 
performed along with cholecystectomy or it can be performed later (two-stage procedure). Given below is a plain X-ray of the erect abdomen showing air in the biliary tract (pneumobilia). A large gallstone causing gallstone ileus is shown below. 758 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 18: In what condition would you see the gallbladder as shown below?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a strawberry gallbladder. Strawberry gallbladder is seen in cholesterolosis 
and is associated with cholesterol stones. Cholesterolosis is characterized by mucosal villous hyperplasia. The interior of the gallbladder 
resembles a strawberry. The yellow specks are aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol 
esters in the lamina propria. This corresponds to the seeds of a strawberry. Option A: Cholesterol polyposis - Cholecystography or ultrasonography shows negative shadows 
in a functioning gallbladder, indicating the presence of a well-defined polyp. Options B and C: Cholecystitis glandularis proliferans/adenomyomatosis - All layers of the 
gallbladder wall may be thickened, but sometimes, an incomplete septum forms that separate the 
hyperplastic from the normal layer. Intraparietal "mixed" calculi may be present.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 40-year-old lady presented with colicky abdominal pain, jaundice and generalized pruritus. 
She has a palpable gallbladder. Which of the following is the least likely cause?

options.a: Stone impacted in the cystic duct
options.b: Stone impacted in the fundus of gallbladder
options.c: Stone impacted within the gallbladder and common bile duct
options.d: Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas

questions.explanation:
A stone impacted within the fundus of the gallbladder is least likely to cause jaundice with a 
palpable gallbladder. According to Courvoisier's law, the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mild 
jaundice, is unlikely due to gallstones. It usually indicates a possibility of carcinoma in the head of 
the pancreas. However, apart from a cancer in the pancreatic head, certain other conditions may 
also cause a palpable gallbladder in presence of jaundice. For example, • Double impacted stones (stones in both the cystic duct and the distal common bile duct) • Primary CBD stone • Oriental cholangiohepatitis 759 
Sold by @itachibot • Mirizzi's syndrome (an impacted gallstone in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder due to 
inflammation, causing common bile duct (CBD) obstruction, jaundice and a palpable gallbladder) These are considered exceptions to Courvoisier's law.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 40-year-old lady presented with abdominal pain, vomiting and jaundice. Her ALP and 
direct bilirubin levels were raised. She had undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy 1 year 
back. On USG there is dilatation of biliary radicles. Which of the following is the ideal 
management for this patient?

options.a: Laparoscopic exploration of common bile duct
options.b: Open surgical exploration of common bile duct
options.d: Addition of ursodeoxycholic acid, followed by repeat USG after 10 days

questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of choledocholithiasis. When diagnosed postoperatively (after 
cholecystectomy), it should be managed with ERCP + sphincterotomy. Stone detected within 2 years after cholecystectomy is called retained stone. Stone detected more 
than 2 years after cholecystectomy is considered recurrent stone. CBD stone and GB stone detected before cholecystectomy: • ERCP+Sphincterotomy, followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy after a few days should be 
done. CBD stone detected during surgery (intraoperatively): • Laparoscopic cholecystectomy + laparoscopic CBD exploration should ideally be done in the 
same sitting to avoid the need for additional operative sitting and anaesthesia. • A transcystic approach is preferred usually. • If there is a small, friable cystic duct; numerous (more than eight) stones in the common bile 
duct; and large stones (>1 cm), laparoscopic choledocholithotomy is performed. • If laparoscopic choledocholithotomy exploration is not feasible, it would necessitate the need for 
an open CBD exploration. • A T-tube is placed in the CBD after laparoscopic choledocholithotomy or open CBD exploration. 
It is followed by a cholangiography to exclude retained stone. CBD stone detected after surgery: • Endoscopic removal (ERCP) with sphincterotomy is usually the management of choice.

questions.question:
Question 21: An 80-year-old woman presented with complaints of fatigue. On imaging, she was found to 
have a scleroatrophic gall bladder with impacted stones in it. A large stone was also present in 
the common bile duct and the biliary tree is dilated. What is the next step in management?

options.a: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.explanation:
An 80-year-old woman with imaging showing a scleroatrophic gall bladder with impacted stones 
and a stone in the bile duct is suggestive of chronic cholelithiasis with choledocholithiasis. ERCP 
is the next line of management for this patient. Choledocholithiasis is the presence of stone in the common bile duct (CBD) or biliary tree. It can 
be primary or secondary: • Primary stones are formed in the CBD or biliary tree itself and are rare. • Secondary stones are passed from the gallbladder to the CBD. They are easier to manage than 
primary stones. It can be an asymptomatic and incidental finding or present with features such as jaundice (most 
common), abdominal pain, and fatigue. When there is inflammation of the biliary tree 760 
Sold by @itachibot (cholangitis), the patient will have intermittent pain, fever, and jaundice (Charcot's triad). Investigations: • Liver function tests will show elevated direct bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. • Abdominal ultrasound is the first imaging modality done and may show gallstones and dilated 
bile duct (>8 mm). • CT is sensitive for CBD stones. It shows stones, location, ductal stricture or block, ductal 
dilatation, and intrahepatic biliary changes. • MRCP is highly sensitive and specific for CBD stones, but it is only diagnostic and intervention 
cannot be performed. Management: • ERCP with sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice, followed by the removal of stones using a 
dormia basket or placement of a stent. • Despite ERCP being an invasive procedure, it has the advantage of being both a diagnostic and 
therapeutic procedure and is more suited for elderly patients who cannot tolerate anesthesia and 
surgery. Other options: Option A: Cholecystectomy is not recommended for elderly patients, owing to the risk of old age 
and associated anesthetic and surgical complications. Option C: Wait and watch approach can be done for asymptomatic patients, and patients with 
smaller stones. Option D: CT is sensitive for CBD stones, but it is only diagnostic and intervention cannot be 
performed.

questions.question:
Question 22: 739 
Sold by @itachibot What is the best investigation in a patient suspected to have an impacted gallstone at the 
ampulla of Vater?
questions.explanation:
Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) will be the best investigation in the 
management of impacted stone at the ampulla of Vater. It allows the surgeon to visualize the 
presence of gallstone at the ampulla of Vater along with the therapeutic extraction of the stone. The following image shows an ERCP procedure (endoscope visible). 761 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following features are part of Reynold's pentad?
questions.explanation:
Vomiting and diaphoresis are not part of Reynold's pentad. Reynold's pentad is seen in acute 
suppurative cholangitis.

questions.question:
Question 24: A jaundiced patient presented with complaints of colicky abdominal pain and itching all over 
the body. USG abdomen showed thickening of the gallbladder wall and pericholecystic fluid. 
MRCP showed extrinsic compression of the common bile duct, suggestive of Mirizzi 
syndrome. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

options.a: Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, gallbladder, and the stone
options.b: Cystic duct obstruction will be present
options.c: Fistula forms between the gallbladder and common bile duct

questions.explanation:
A palpable gallbladder will not rule out gallstones in Mirizzi syndrome. It is an exception to 
Courvoisier's law. Courvoisier's law states that in the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mild 
jaundice, the cause is unlikely to be gallstones. Its exceptions include: • Double impacted stones (stones in both the cystic duct and the distal common bile duct) • Primary CBD stone • Oriental cholangiohepatitis • Mirizzi's syndrome In Mirizzi’s syndrome, gallstones become impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder 
due to inflammation. This causes common bile duct (CBD) obstruction and jaundice. The 
gallbladder is distended and may be palpable. ERCP, PTC (Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography), or MRCP will usually demonstrate the 
characteristic extrinsic compression of the CBD. Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, diseased gallbladder, and the impacted stone. In 
patients whose gallbladder is densely adherent to the common bile duct, partial cholecystectomy 
should be done. 762

(cholecysto-choledochal fistula).

The given image shows a resected specimen of a gallbladder with a polyp on the inner surface. Specimen of gallbladder carcinoma would include an en-bloc dissection of the gall bladder, 
surrounding liver tissue and regional lymph nodes (option D). In specimens of cholesterolosis, 
also known as strawberry gallbladder, the gall bladder would appear yellow and coarsely granular 
due to the presence lipid nodules (options A and B). Gall bladder polyps are usually incidental findings during abdominal imaging. Most of them are 
benign and comprise cholesterol polyps, adenomyomas or inflammatory polyps. Adenomatous 
polyps are the most common neoplastic polyps. The majority of patients with polyps are stable 
and smaller polyps are kept under observation. Cholecystectomy is done for symptomatic patients 
(biliary colic, pancreatitis), patients >50 years, sessile polyps with thickening >4 mm and 
polyps >10 mm. The risk factors for malignancy in an adenomatous polyp include age >50 years, size >10 
mm, sessile polyp, documented increase in size, and coexistence with gallstones. Other options: Option D: The gallbladder in a patient with carcinoma is removed via an en-bloc dissection with 
surrounding liver tissue along with regional lymph nodes. The given image below shows a cut 
surface of the resected gallbladder with a tumor at the neck along with liver bed involvement 
(marked by the red arrow). Options A and B: Cholesterolosis (strawberry gallbladder) is characterized by the accumulation of 
lipids (triglycerides, cholesterol precursors and cholesterol esters) in the lamina propria of the 
gallbladder wall. The nodules are less than 1 mm in diameter and there is mucous villous 
hyperplasia, which gives it a coarse, yellow and granular appearance, giving it a strawberry-like 763

Question 26: A 45-year old lady is found to have a gall bladder polyp of size 1.2cm on abdominal USG. She 
appears to be healthy and is asymptomatic. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
Gallbladder polyps larger than 1 cm have an increased risk of malignancy and should be treated by 
performing a cholecystectomy.

questions.question: Question 28: All of the following are risk factors for gallbladder carcinoma, except:
questions.explanation:
Adenomyomatosis is not a risk factor for carcinoma gallbladder. Adenomyomatosis is a benign condition of the gallbladder characterized by hypertrophy of the 
mucosal epithelium. It invaginates into the thickened muscularis forming Rokitansky-Aschoff 
sinuses. Risk factors for carcinoma gallbladder: • Gallstones of size >3 cm (most important risk factor) • Porcelain gallbladder • Anomalous pancreato-biliary junction • Choledochal cyst • Adenomatous polyps • Primary sclerosing cholangitis • Obesity • Salmonella typhii infection.

questions.question: Question 29: Which of the following is false regarding gallbladder carcinoma?

options.a: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type
options.c: Depth of invasion is the most important prognostic factor

questions.explanation:
The most common type of gallbladder carcinoma is adenocarcinoma (80–90%). Squamous 
carcinomas also occur and are believed to arise from areas of mucosal squamous metaplasia. Gallbladder carcinoma is a rare malignancy that is seen in the elderly. It is associated with a poor 
prognosis and is indistinguishable from cholecystitis or cholelithiasis. It is usually diagnosed 
when patients undergo cholecystectomy for gallstones. Its clinical features include right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Jaundice 
is a late feature. CA 19-9 is elevated in the carcinoma gallbladder and is used for monitoring. The preoperative diagnosis is often made on ultrasonography and followed up by a CT scan or 
MRI/Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography. A percutaneous biopsy under radiological guidance is done for pathological examination. PET 
scanning helps in detecting metastatic disease. In select cases, a laparoscopic examination is useful in staging the disease. Laparoscopy can also 
detect peritoneal or liver metastases. The most important prognostic factor is the depth of 
invasion (T-stage). 765

questions.question:
Question 30: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. Histopathology of the 
resected gall bladder is reported as Stage T1a of gallbladder cancer. What is the next step in 
management?
questions.explanation:
Cholecystectomy is sufficient for gallbladder carcinoma with T1a lesions, wherein the tumor 
penetrates the lamina propria but does not invade the muscle layer. Treatment of gallbladder carcinoma (in general): If the carcinoma gall bladder was found incidentally after cholecystectomy: • Up to stage Ia and stage Ib with negative margins, standard cholecystectomy would suffice • Stage Ib with perineural, lymphatic, vascular invasion and stage II, extended cholecystectomy 
should be performed If the initial procedure was performed laparoscopically, the surgeon should examine the 
laparoscopic port sites. The finding of disease at the port sites is a sign of generalized peritoneal 
disease and carries a very poor prognosis. However, resection of port sites is no longer 
recommended. Chemotherapy is not required in early gall bladder cancer. Radiation has no role. TNM sta
